results.title: Myths of nationalism
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Towards the end of the 19th century, there was, in Europe, a second wave of industrialisation with a more advanced technology. This considers each of the major powers within Europe in relation to this new technology, in the years leading up to the Great War of 1914-18.

results.title: Towards a modern Europe: the Renaissance
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Explains and illustrates the transition from the Middle Ages to the Renaissance, including the principles of the new study and attitudes in art, architecture and scholarship

results.title: The Middle Ages
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
History of the Middle Ages from Charlemagne examined through art, monasteries, agriculture and invasions. Illustrated by 15th century miniatures, the film gives a good background to European history, literature and art.

results.title: The Romans
results.creator_credit: John Dooley and Polonius Film Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “An Outline History of Europe”.
Presents the origins, growth and collapse of the Roman Empire. Describes how the Romans imitated the greek ideal of the city state and how they expanded over a period of 400 years, emerging as the ruling force of the world. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Trading (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines from central and coastal districts trade their specialities among themselves, in particular weapons of the hunt and of war. Leaving his family at their inland mia-mia, the man travels through dense bush to barter with another Aborigine, so that each may benefit from the other’s skills. They sit face to face and test each weapon for strength before returning with their new possessions. With Bill Onus.

group_siblings.title: Making a bark canoe (A)
group_siblings.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Bark canoe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows the primitive methods of canoe manufacture employed by the Australian Aborigine. Illustrates the removal of bark from a tree in a single section, its shaping and testing, and finally the canoe’s use for fishing. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Shellfish gathering
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “Alcheringa”.
Migratory habits of inland Aborigines who go walkabout to the coast to collect shellfish at certain times of the year, to augment their diet. The husband walks ahead and carries his fire sticks in his hair. His wife goes into the rock pools and quickly fills the string bag which hangs from her shoulder; cooks the fish in their shells in the hot ash; water is poured over the fire to cool the shellfish before they are removed and eaten.

results.title: Boomerang (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Demonstrates how the aborigine crafts the boomerang. The diligent search for the exact right piece of wood, the burning off of the outer bark, the tedious, laborious whittling with a sharpended stone and the fashioning of the slight twist at each end to git it its unique quality of returning to its point of departure. Introduced by Bill Onus.

results.title: Mutton birds
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Aborigines gather eggs and hunt the mutton bird on small coastal islands. The birds are removed from their burrows, killed and plucked before being loaded onto bark floats to be carried through the surf back to the camp fire.
